Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Undergraduate Research on Neutron-Rich Nuclei
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports research at Augustana College (a small, undergraduate-only, liberal arts institution) to understand the structure of radioactive nuclei that have many excess neutrons. The National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) at Michigan State University (MSU) produces radioactive beams with these excess neutrons. The beams are incident upon a target and the products of the nuclear reactions are measured in a variety of subatomic particle detectors. An important part of the project is the involvement of undergraduate students in these experiments and in development of the necessary detector instrumentation. Undergraduate research experience is important for many future technical careers as well as for graduate school. The funds for this award support the work of the undergraduates and the principle investigator to design and run experiments at NSCL, to analyze data, and to give talks and write papers on the results.

Experiments on exotic nuclear systems are necessary to place constraints on modern theoretical models. The nuclei studied as part of this project are neutron-unbound, which means that a neutron is emitted from a nucleus shortly after formation. Since the nuclei are so unstable, the radioactive nuclear ion beam at NSCL is utilized for these experiments. The charged particle left over after neutron emission is bent by the Sweeper Magnet into a suite of charged particle detectors. The emitted neutron is detected by the MoNA-LISA (Modular Neutron Array and the Large-area multi-Institutional Scintillator Array). The research in this proposal involves data analysis of neutron-unbound nuclear systems and on-going equipment development. New data on the 24O(d,p) reaction will be taken to study negative parity states in 25O. The Augustana-MSU hodoscope, assembled, tested and installed by the Augustana nuclear group, is a key device for this experiment. In addition, the PI will work on the design, construction, and use of a new segmented target system for future experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The undergraduate nuclear physics research group at Augustana College was supported by this grant to study neutron-rich nuclides, and to maintain and improve experimental equipment. These studies were performed using the facility located at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory located on the campus of Michigan State University (MSU). Undergraduate Augustana students and the primary investigator worked on experiment design, participation and analysis, and dissemination of experimental results with investigators from the MoNA (Modular Neutron Array) collaboration. Through this work, undergraduate students gained valuable research experience that helped them pursue their career goals or achieve acceptance into graduate school.

The Intellectual Merit of the supported work included studies of neutron-rich nuclides to improve our theoretical understanding of these systems, and to maintain and develop experimental devices. Members of the Augustana research team participated in experiments and analyses on nuclides 23N, 24-26O, 31Ne, and 25,26F produced in three different experiments. The primary investigator and undergraduate students were co-authors on published works. The research team worked on two devices, a hodoscope and segmented target, used in experiments to measure charged particles. The hodoscope aged and has begun repairs by MoNA collaborators. The segmented target system performed well and will continue to be used in future experiments. Finally, a new charged particle detector telescope concept was developed and funded to improve the detection efficiencies of complex experiments.

The Broader Impacts of the work was in providing opportunities to do research at a R1 level facility for Augustana undergraduates and collaborating on analyses with graduate student researchers at MSU and undergraduates from the MoNA collaboration. A total of six undergraduates participated in this work. Half of the students are in or are actively applying to STEM graduate school programs, while the other half are employed. The Augustana team worked on analyses with multiple institutions and graduate students within the collaboration, which helped analyses move forward to publication.
